conclusion: Mass of block A is 1 kg, mass of block B is 2 kg, maximum static friction force between A and B is 1 N, coefficient of kinetic friction between B and ground is 0.1, gravitational acceleration is 10 m/s².
For blocks A and B to remain relatively stationary, the friction force between them must be sufficient to prevent relative motion.
Weight of A is 10 N downward, normal force from B is 10 N upward, horizontal friction force from B is directed opposite to potential relative motion.

Weight of B is 20 N downward, normal force from ground is 30 N upward, normal force on A is 10 N downward, applied force F is rightward, friction force between B and A is opposite direction to friction on A, friction force between B and ground.
When applied force F increases, if net force trying to cause relative motion is greater than 1 N, blocks will slide relative to each other.
For A to accelerate with B without relative motion, friction force must equal mass of A times acceleration.
If blocks move together with acceleration, using Newton's second law: F - friction force on ground equals combined mass times acceleration.
Friction force between B and ground is 3 N, so F - 3 equals 3 times acceleration.
For block A to not slip relative to B, friction force must not exceed maximum static friction of 1 N.
Maximum acceleration before slipping is 1 m/s².
Using equation for acceleration, maximum force F is 6 N.
The condition for keeping A and B relatively stationary is that the horizontal force F does not exceed 6 N.
